ARE YOU OUT OF YOUR MIND
LET'S GO LET'S GO LET'S GO

WE ESTIMATE TWO LARGE ADULTS HEADED
ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE DOOR,
THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD OF THE FRONT TRAILER,
THE FRONT END OFF THE GROUND
GO GO GO GO GOG GO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 135-foot-luxury yacht is anchored just offshore in a tropical lagoon. The beach is a stunning crescent of whit sand at the jungle fringe, utterly deserted.

dialogues.speaker: ISLA SORNA
dialogues.text: 87 miles southeast of Nublar Two SHIP HANDS, dressed in white uniforms, have set up a picnic table with three chairs on the sand and are carefu laying out luncheon service -- fine china, silver, crysta decanters with red and white wine. PAUL BOWMAN, fortyish, sits in a chair off to the side, reading. MRS. BOWMAN, painfully thin, with the perpetuall surprised look of a woman who's had her eyes done more th once, supervises the settings of the table. She looks up and sees a little girl, CATHY, seven or eigh years old, wandering off down the beach.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Cathy! Don't wander off! Cathy keeps wandering. MRS. BOWMAN (cont'd) Cathy, come back! You can look for shells right here! Cathy gestures, pretending she can't hear.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: (eyes still in his book) Leave her alone.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BOWMAN
dialogues.text: What about snakes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no snakes on a beach. Let her have fun, for once.

dialogues.speaker: FURTHER DOWN THE BEACH,
dialogues.text: Cathy keeps wandering away, MUTTERING to herself as her parents' quarreling voices fade in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Please be quiet, please be quiet please be quiet... Rounding a curve in the beach, her parents disappear from behind her. A RUSTLING sound draws her attention, and she turns, toward where the thick jungle foliage gives way to sand. A large bush, maybe twelve feet tall, is moving, its bran swaying and shaking. Curious, Cathy walks up to the bush, which abruptly stops moving. A small, lizard-like animal, dark green with brown stripe along its back, steps out from the bush. Only about a foo tall, it stands on its hind legs, balancing on its thick It walks upright, bobbing its head like a chicken.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: Well, hello there! The animal (a COMPSOGNATHUS) just stares at her. Cathy sq down on her haunches. CATHY (cont'd) What are you? A little bird or something? She opens her hand. She's got a handful of goldfish crack CATHY (cont'd) Are you hungry? You want a goldfish? The compy bobs forward a few steps, cautiously. CATHY (cont'd) Come on. I won't hurt you. The compy draws closer. Cathy holds the cracker in the pa of her hand. The compy gets closer still -- -- and hops numbly up onto Cathy's palm. Her arm dips a b under the weight, but it's not that heavy, and she holds easily. It bobs its head, scarfs up the goldfish, and eat it. Enchanted, Cathy breaks into an enormous grin and returns  hand, calling back over her shoulder. CATHY (cont'd) Mom! Dad! You gotta come see this! I found something! She turns back. Thirty more compys have come out onto the sand. They're Standing there, bobbing anxiously, staring at her froma f feet away. Cathy's smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns her head slowly to the right. TWENTY MORE COMPY have come in from that side, forming a semi-circle, bobbi and CHIPPING as they surround her. CATHY (cont'd) (terrified) What do you guys want?

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON THE BEACH,
dialogues.text: the table is set. Mrs. Bowman calls out.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Cathy, sweetheart! Lunch is ready! From around the curve of the beach, a flock of birds bolt from the jungle trees as Cathy's shrill SCREAMS suddenly pierce the air.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She takes off, running down the beach, Mr. Bowman leaps o his chair and follows, and all available deck hands race to help, kicking up geysers of sand behind them.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE BEACH,
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bowman stops dead in her tracks when she rounds the in the beach. We don't see what she sees, but we hear the frenzied SQUEAKING of the strange compys. Mr. Bowman and Hands race past her to help Cathy as Mrs. Bowman lets loo horrified, slack-jawed SCREAM, her mouth a perfect oval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bowman's screaming face dissolves slowly over the YAWNING face of a bored CORPORATE EXECUTIVE, TWENTY OTHER EXECUTIVES sit around a conference table in the boardroom monied corporation. All are in expensive suits, most are sixty. There are rows of BACKBENCHERS too, whispering in lawyers who sit behind their clients, whispering in their ears. Empty coffee cups and fast food containers on the t  hint that everyone's been here a long time. A familiar VOICE resounds through the boardroom as we mov down the long table, pat the grim faces of the board memb

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The hurricane seemed like a disaster at the time, but now I think it was a blessing, nature's way of freeing those animals from their human confines. Of giving them another chance to survive, but this time as they were meant to, without man's interference. The source of the voice is JOHN HAMMOND, the founder of I and creator of Jurassic Park. But he's not in the room. H image is on a closed circuit TV screen, which has been wh up to the end of the table. And he doesn't look good. He's terribly infirmed, propped in bed, his face pale and drawn, medical equipment BEEPIN around him. HAMMOND (cont'd) There are some corporate issues that are not about the bottom line. We have so much still to learn about those creatures. A whole world of intricate, interlocking behaviors, vanished everywhere -- except for site B. Please. Let's not do what is good for more men at the expense at what is best for all mankind. The CHAIRMAN, seventyish, nods awkwardly to the televisio

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, John. Mr. Ludlow? He turns to PETER LUDLOW, late thirties, a man with the anxious look of someone who insists the buck stop on his Ludlow flips open a file, pulls out a stack of black and eight by tens, and tosses them on the table.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (an accent similar to Hammond's) These pictures were taken ina hospital in Costa Rica forty-eight hours ago, after an American family on a yacht cruise stumbled onto Site B. The little girl will be fine, but her parents are wealthy, angry, and very fond of lawsuits. But that's hardly new to us, is it? (takes a paper from the  file) Wrongful death settlements, partial list: family of Donald Gennaro, 36.5 million dollars; family of Robert Muldoon, 12.6 million. Damaged or destroyed equipment, 17.3 million. Demolition, de-construction, and disposal of Isla Nublar facilities, organic and inorganic, one hundred and twenty-six million dollars. The Tist goes on, gentlemen -- research funding, media payoffs. Silence is expensive. He's warming up. Not a bad performer. LUDLOW (cont'd) This corporation has been bleeding from the throat for four years. You, our board of directors, have set patiently and listened to ecology lectures while Mr. Hammond signed your checks and spent your money. You have watched your stock drop from seventy-eight and a quarter to nineteen flat with no good and in sight. And all along, we have held a significant product asset that we could have safely harvested and displayed for profit. Enormous profit. He reaches out to a model on the table and gives it a sho sending it sliding down the length of the table in front them. It's a mini-mall version of a zoo. Cages hold tiny replicas of various kinds of dinosaurs while Boy Scout tr and Tourists look on in wonder. LUDLOW (cont'd) Enough money to wipe out four years of lawsuits and damage control and unpleasant infighting, enough to not only send our stock back to where it was but to double it. And the one thing, the only thing standing between us and this asset is a born-again naturalist who happens to be our own CEO. Well, I don't work for Mother Nature. I work for you. Two of his Backbenchers distribute documents from a stack Ludlow takes one and reads from it. LUDLOW (cont'd) "Whereas the Chief Executive Officer has engaged in wasteful and negligent business practices to  further his own personal environmental beliefs -- Whereas these practices have affected the financial performance of the company by incurring significant losses -- Whereas the shareholders have been materially harmed by these losses -- Thereby, be it resolved that John Parker Hammond should be resolved from the office of Chief Executive Officer, affective immediately." Mr. Chairman, I move the resolution be put to an immediate vote. Do I have a second?

dialogues.speaker: BOARD MEMBER
dialogues.text: I second the motion, Mr. Chairman, Please poll the members by a show of hands. The CHAIRMAN signs heavily, feeling like a traitor. He ca bear to look at Hammond on the TV monitor.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: All those in favor of InGen Corporate Resolution 213C, please signify your approval by raising your right hand. It starts slowly, guiltily, but every hand in the room go up. Ludlow sits back, victorious. Hammond, furious, raise his right hand, which holds a remote control, and points the TV screen. It goes blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparks fly out the windows and doors of a shed in the mid of a welder's yard. Scrap iron and steel lies everywhere. Somewhere inside the shed, a phone RINGS. The WHOOSH of the arc welder shuts off. DIETER STARK, a b barrel-chested man of forty or so, his face streaked with and grime, steps outside with a cordless phone, a cigaret dangling from his lips.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Yeah. He takes a deep drag while someone talks on the other end smiles and blows out a cloud of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke turns into steam as a subway THUNDER into a station underneath Manhattan. The door WHOOSH open, spit out som COMMUTERS and suck up a few more. A tall man hurries down the platform, limping heavily, mo as fast as he can. The subway doors begin to close, but j before they meet -- -- the man jams a cane in between, stopping them. The man is IAN MALCOLM, fortyish, dressed in black from head to t There's a hard wisdom in Malcolm's eyes that may not have there's a few years ago -- he know what you think, and he doesn't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MALCOLM finds a seat on the crowded subway car and sits d He looks awful. Tired. Weathered. He notices a CURIOUS MA across from his is staring at his. Malcolm looks away. Th Curious Man still stares. Nervy, the Curious Man gets up approaches.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Shit. The Curious Man sits down next to Malcolm, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You're him, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: The guy. The scientist. I saw you on TV. (conspiratorially) I believed you. No response from Malcolm. The guy leans in even closer. MAN (cont'd) Roooooarr.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: (a withering look) I was misquoted. I was merely speculating on the evolutionary scenario of a Lost World. I never said I was in any such place. He gets up and moves to another seat on the car, away fro Curious Man. As he sits down, he notices two other COMMUT across from him are staring at him. He looks at them. They looks away. He pulls the collar of his coat up tight around him. Now to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A UNIFORMED BUTLER has a question:

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: Whom shall I tell Mr. Hammond is calling? MALCOLM stands in the foyer of an expensively decorated P Avenue apartment.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Tan Malcolm A door opens and a little dog comes YAPPING out of the ba It bounds straight at Malcolm, GROWLING, jaws SNAPPING. I lunges -- -- and Malcolm BATS it away with one swift swing of his c The dog rolls across the floor and slinks away, WHINING. Butler looks at Malcolm disapprovingly.

dialogues.speaker: BUTLER
dialogues.text: Not an animal lover?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MALCOLM enters a darkened bedroom. JOHN HAMMOND lies in t bed we saw earlier, on the other side of the room; Medical equipment has been disguised as well as possible the furniture and flowers, but the sheer abundance of it us that whatever has stricken him is going to win this ba

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: Ian! Don't linger in the doorway like an ingenue, come in, come in! Malcolm steps further into the room. HAMMOND (cont'd) It's good to see you. It really is. How's the leg?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Resentful.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: When you have a lot of time to think, it's funny who you remember. It's the people who challenged you. It is  the quality of our opponents that gives our accomplishments meaning. I never told you how sorry I was about what happened after we returned. Noticing Hammond's deteriorated condition, Malcolm finds hard to Malcolm sustain anger.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I didn't know you -- weren't well.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: It's the lawyers. The lawyers are finally killing me.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: They do have motives. Why did you want to see me? Your message said it was urgent.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: You were right -- and I was wrong. There! Did you ever think you'd hear me say that? Spectacularly wrong. Instead of observing those animals, I tried to control them. I squandered an opportunity and we still know next to nothing about their lives. Not their lives as man would have them, behind electric fences, but in the wild. Behavior in their natural habitat, the impossible dream of any paleontologist. I could have had it, but I let it slip away. (pause) Thank God for Site B. just looks at him for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: (a spark in his eye) Well? Didn't it all seem a trifle compact to you?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: The hatchery, in particular? You know my initial yields had to be low, far less than one percent, that's a thousand embryos for every single live birth. Genetic engineering on that scale implies a giant operation,  not the spotless little laboratory I showed you.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: Isla Nublar was just a showroom, Ian, something for the tourists, Site B was the factory floor. We built it first, on Isla Sorna, eight-some miles from Nublar.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no, no, no. .

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: After the accident at the park, a hurricane wiped out our facility on Site B. We had to evacuate and leave the animals to fend for themselves. And they did. For four years I've fought to keep them safe from human meddling, now I want you to go there and document them.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind? I still have nightmares, my reputation's a joke, my leg is shot -- you think I need more of that?

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: It would be the most extraordinary living fossil record the world has ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: So what? Hammonnd picks up a thick file folder from the night tabl to him and open it on his lap. Inside, there are memos, charts, maps and photographs.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: I've been putting this together for over a year. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have personal suggestions for your entire team, phone numbers, contact people. They won't believe you about what they're going to see, so don't bother trying to convince them. Just use my checkbook to get them there. I'll fund your expedition through my personal accounts, as such money and equipment as you need, but only if  Malcolm Malcolm you leave immediately. If we hesitate, all will be lost.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: John...

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: You'll need an animal behaviorist, someone with unimpeachable credentials. I believe you already know Sarah Harding. She's got theories about parenting and nurturing among hunter/scavengers I bet she'd be dying to prove on a scale like this. If you convince her to go, it'll be a major coup. When she publishes, the scientific community must take it seriously. just shakes his head, flipping through the file sadly.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: Your documentation, you should use forensic photographic methods, Hasselbladt still cameras, high definition video. When the trick photography analysts take your evidence apart, make it impossible for them to say there was enhancement or computer graphic imaging. 0h, this is very important -- avoid the island interior at all costs. Stick to the outer rim. Everything you need to know can be found there. Vindication lies on the outer rim. gently closes the file and pushes it back to Hammond.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I'm not going, John.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: (fatigue returning) Ian, you are my last chance to give something of real value to the world. I can't walk so far and leave no footprints; die and leave nothing with my name on it. I will not be known only for my failures. And you will not allow yourself to go down in history as a lunatic. You're too smart. You'e too proud. Dr. Malcolm. Please. This is a chance at redemption. For both of us. There's no time to equivocate, we must seize it now, before --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, staring over Malcom's shoulder. Malcom turns. PETER LUDLOW, still in his overcoat, is standing in the doorway to the bedroom. He looks back and forth from Hamm to Malcolm suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Hello, Uncle John. Dr. Malcolm. Malcolm doesn't answer. He seems to know Ludlow, and disl him. LUDLOW (cont'd) Did I interrupt something? Malcolm turns back to Hammond.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Find someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the foyer, LUDLOW hands MALCOLM his coat, just a trifl rudely, and shepherds him to the door.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: So, you two were just, uh, telling old campfire stories, were you?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Do me a favor. Don't pretend for a second that you and I don't know the truth. You can convince Time magazine and the Skeptical Inquirer of whatever you want, but I was there.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You signed a non-disclosure agreement before you went to the island that expressly forbade you from discussing anything you saw. You violated that agreement.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You cost me my livelihood. That on which I relied to support my children.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: If your university felt you were causing it embarrassment by selling wild stories to Hard Copy, I hardly see how I am to--

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I didn't tell anything, I told the truth.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: You version of it.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: There are no versions of the truth! This isn't a corporate maneuver, it's my life.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: We made a generous compensatory offer for your injuries.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: It was a payoff and an insult. InGen never--

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: InGen is my livelihood, Dr. Malcolm, and I will jealously defend its interests. People will know what I want them to know when I want them to know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ludlow tosses something to Malcolm, hard. It sails across foyer, upright, and Malcolm reaches out and catches it wi one hand. It's his cane. LUDLOW (cont'd) Don't forget that. Malcolm stares at him for a long moment. Finally, he turn and walks away. But he does not out of the apartment. Instead, he walks directly past Ludlow, crosses the living room, and back into Hammond's bedroom, closing the door behind him a determined CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAMMOND looks up, hopeful, as MALCOLM comes back into the and walks over to his bed. He reaches down -- -- and picks up the file folder.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Do you have a satellite phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROLAND TEMBO, late sixties, skin like leather and the dia hard look of a cobra, sits at a table in the middle of an  African cafe/bar in Mombassa. It's daytime and the place is half full, mostly with loca but there are a few obnoxious TOURISTS too, Americans on safari who somehow found the local handout. They're a noisy bunch, but Roland tunes them out, calmly eating his lunch and drinking a beer while he reads a boo eyeglasses hanging low on his nose. Roland suddenly stops reading and furrows his brow. He lo up. He SNIFFS the air once, then smiles and calls out a person's name.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Ajay? He turns around. AJAY (AH-jay) SIDHU, a wiry East Indian his late forties, is standing behind him, caught trying t sneak up.

dialogues.speaker: AJAY
dialogues.text: (delighted) How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (taps his nose) That cheap aftershave I send you every Christmas, you actually wear it. I'm touched. Sit down, sit down, what brings you to Mombassa?

dialogues.speaker: AJAY
dialogues.text: You. Tell me, Roland, when was the last time you answered your phone?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Last time I plugged it in, I suppose. Why? Behind them, the group of TOURISTS, all men, laughs loudl One of them, the MOST OBNOXIOUS TOURISTS, berates the WAI

dialogues.speaker: AJAY
dialogues.text: I got a call from a gentleman who's going to Costa Rica, or thereabouts. If he's to be believed, it's a most, uh, unique expedition. And very well-funded.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Well, I'ma very well-funded old son of a bitch. You go. The Most Obnoxious Tourist bellows for the Waitress. His buddies LAUGHS. Roland throws a glance, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But alone? We always had great success together, you and I.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Just a little bit too much, I think.

dialogues.speaker: AJAY
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: A true hunter doesn't mind if the animal wins. If it escapes. But there weren't enough escapes from you and me, Ajay. I've decided to spend a bit less time in the company of death. Maybe I just feel too close to it my-- The Waitress comes to the Tourists' table and the Most Obnoxious Tourist actually paws her ass. Roland is out of chair in a second. ROLAND (cont'd) (to Ajay) Excuse me. Romand walks over to the Tourists' table, says something the Waitress in the local dialect, and she walks away, be him. He stares down at the Most Obnoxious Tourist. ROLAND (cont'd) You, sir -- are no gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST
dialogues.text: Is that supposed to be an insult?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: I can think of none greater. The Tourist looks at his Buddies and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST
dialogues.text: Buzz off, you silly old bastard.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: What do I have to do to pick a fight with you, bring your mother into it?

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I could take you with one arm tied down.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the Waiter finishes tying a man's wrist to his belt in th back of his pants with a napkin. He pulls the knot tight the man turns around. It's Roland, with his arm tied down. The Tourist stands across from him.

dialogues.speaker: TOURIST
dialogues.text: I mean my arm, POW! Roland punches him square in the jaw. The Tourist reels, stunned. Enraged, he lunges at Roland, swinging wi both arms. Roland bobs, neatly ducking the punches, waits for the To to turn around, and POPS him thrice in the face. The Tour spins and goes down to the floor, face first. A cloud of sawdust and a loud CHEER from the locals rise up in the b

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT HIS TABLE,
dialogues.text: Roland drops the napkin on the table and sits back down w Ajay. In the background, the Tourist's Buddies hurriedly carry their fallen cohort out of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Sorry. We were saying?

dialogues.speaker: AJAY
dialogues.text: You broke that idiot's jaw for no reason other than your boredom. Tell the truth, Roland. Aren't you even interested in knowing this expedition's quarry?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Ajay. Go on up to my ranch, take a look around the trophy room, and tell me what kind of quarry you think could possibly be of any interest to me. — Ajay just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The African savannah appears in shades of fluorescent gre seen through night-vision goggles. An ANIMAL YELP comes f the left and the green vista sweeps abruptly toward it. T world blurs momentarily, then comes into focus on a field long grass. The grass ripples in a complex pattern as animals move  stealthily through it. One animal head pops up above the grass for a split-second, teeth bared, a white stripe bet its eyes. SARAH HARDING pulls the goggles away from her f

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hyenas. Ace Face is the striped snout. Sarah is thirty, with a compact, athletic body built for outdoors. She loos through the goggles again, sweeping ah of the hyenas to their prey. It's a herd of African buffalo, standing belly-deep in th grass, agitated, bellowing and stamping their feet. Sarah turns to MAKENA, her African assistant. SARAH (cont'd) They'll try to take down a calf. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: MAKENA
dialogues.text: Closer? Sarah scurries up and over a rock face. Makena follows. Closer now, they watch as the hyenas rush the herd, runni through it, trying to break it up. MAKENA (cont'd) You know, we could see everything from up on the edge of that cliff.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: MAKENA
dialogues.text: But the view would --

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No cliffs. (into a pocket recorder) Fl headed sough, F2 and F5 flanking, twenty yards. F3 center. F6 circling wide east. Can't see F7. While she talks, breathless, fascinated by the drama befo her, Sarah continues to creep closer and closer to the ac Makena follows, with growing unease.

dialogues.speaker: MAKENA
dialogues.text: Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: F8 circling north. Fl straight through, disrupting. Herd moving, stamping. There's F7. Straight through. F8 angling through from the  north. She's practically on top of the animals now.

dialogues.speaker: MAKENA
dialogues.text: Dr. Harding. Makena has a hold of Sarah's sweatshirt and is tugging he back, at least trying to slow down her progress as Sarah, wide-eyed with fascination, creeps even closer. Suddenly there is a tremendous BELLOWING and the grass ri in front of them rips apart, trampled under the feet of t hyenas as they cluster around a fallen buffalo calf. They yelp and jump, their muzzles bloody. The adults move aside, making room as the hyena pups come forward, squealing to get at the kill. Sarah's eyes shine with excitement and she moves even closer, whispering int tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Brooding behavior in evidence at the kill site, pups are ushered forward and adults help them eat, pulling flesh away from the carcass and-- A telephone rings. Sarah stops in mid-sentence, unsure if she heard what she thought she heard. It rings again, the unmistakable CHIRP of a cellular phone. Sarah and Makena both move at once, pawing at a backpack. SARAH (cont'd) (a frantic whisper) I thought you turned it off! Two hyenas look inquisitively in the direction of the pho Sarah comes up with it and jabs at a button in irritation SARAH (cont'd) Yes?! Someone speaks on the other end. Sarah rolls her eyes. SARAH (cont'd) Ian. This better be important. Sarah doesn't say anything for a long moment, just listen the voice on the other end talks. And talks. SARAH (cont'd) When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ian Malcolm's leg, badly scarred, is bared and draped ove end of a bench. Two sandbags are fastened to his ankle an MALCOLM is lifting them, painfully rehabbing his injury w talking on a satellite phone.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: We leave in twenty-four hours. Five member team. Behind them, the SPARKS of a acetylene torch fly as WORKM make modifications on several vehicles, including a dark- Mercedes Benz AAV (all-activity vehicle). The hood of the is up and the V-6 engine has been pulled out; a new, smal engine is lowered in its place. To one side are two long trailers, connected by an accordion-like passageway, like subway car, allowing one to be towed behind the other.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Eddie Carr's handling all our equipment and he'll be there to maintain it. He's designing special field trailers now, top of the line mobile research units. EDDIE CARR, fortyish, is barking out orders to the Workme

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No, no, look at the plans, Henry, you can't place that strut laterally, it has to be crosswise, LOOK AT THE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the ceiling, a large metal age CRASHES down, landing next to them on the floor with a deafening CLANG. They le back and look up. A WORKMAN waves from a scaffolding.

dialogues.speaker: WORKMAN
dialogues.text: Sorry, Eddie! Specs say it can't deform at 12,000 PSI, we had to test it Eddie bends down to inspect the cage, which is rectangula constructed of inch-thick titanium-alloy bars. Malcolm ha up the phone and walks up, joining him.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Any damage?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Minimal.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: "Minimal" is too much. It has to be light, it has to be strong --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light and strong, light and strong, sure, why not, it's only impossible. God save me from academics.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You are an academic.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Former academic. Now I actually make things. I don't just talk.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You think I'm all talk, Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (doesn't look at him) It doesn't matter what I think.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Is there anything we've forgotten? Anything at all? Behind them, someone CLEARS THEIR THROAT. Eddie and Malco turn around. KELLY MALCOLM, an African-American girl arou twelve years old, stands in the doorway to the garage, a duffel bag slung over one shoulder. She looks at Malcolm breaks into a wide grin.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Kelly! What are you doing here? She drops the bag on the floor, and wraps her arms around in a warm embrace. He responds stiffly.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Vacation. I'm all yours. You didn't forget, did you? She pulls back and looks at him. KELLY (cont'd) Did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KELLY is slumped in a chair in Eddie's office next to the construction floor. Outside the glass windows work on the vehicles continues unabated. MALCOLM hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Okay, Karen is expecting you in half  an hour. You only have to stay with her one night, she'll put you on a bus in the morning and your mother will be at the station when you get there.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I don't even know this woman.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Well, I do, and she's fantastic. She'll take you to the museum, maybe to a movie if you play your cards right. You're going to have a fantastic time.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Stop saying fantastic. Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I can't tell you. But I'll be back within a week.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: My vacation is over in a week.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I'll make it up to you this summer. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I'm your daughter all the time, you know. Not just when it's convenient.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: very hurtful. Your mother tell you to say that?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: No, Dad. I have thoughts of my own once in a while. From the construction floor, EDDIE calls out. EDDIE (0.s.) Dr. Malcolm! Malcolm looks at her, trying to make peace. Quickly.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Is that kid still bothering you?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You know, at the bus stop. With the hair?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: That was about a year ago.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Well, is he?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: No. Richard talked to his parents.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: That Richard. EDDIE (o.s.) Ian, come here a minute!

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (to Malcolm) I could come with you.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Out of the question. You'd miss the gymnastics trials. You've been training for that for a year.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I don't care about the trials, I want to be with you. I could be your research assistant, like I was in Austin.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: This is nothing like Austin. Forget about it.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You like to have kids, you just don't want to be with them, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her, hurt. Eddie calls out a third time, impatient now. Grateful for the escape, Malcolm gets up a heads for the door. He pauses guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I'm not like you wan me to be. I've what I can be. He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While MALCOLM and EDDIE argue over something in the background, KELLY circles around the trailers and looks u the windows. They're all made of tempered glass, fine wir mesh inside it. She looks around, to see if anybody's watching. They're not, so she quickly slips inside the f trailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, the trailer is a miracle of planning and design. divided into sections, for different laboratory functions The main area is a biological lab, with specimen trays, dissecting pans, and microscopes that connect to video monitors. Next to it there's an extensive computer section, a bank processors, and a communications section. All the lab equipment is miniaturized and built into small tables tha slides into the walls. Everything is bolted down. She notices a large map on the wall. Off the coat of Cost Rica, there is an area that has been circled in heavy bla ink. Kelly puts a finger on the map, crossing westward, throug Pacific Ocean. Thegre are dozen s of islands out here, bu the highlighted region, there is a semi-circle of five. Matanceros. Muerte. Tacano. Pena. And Sorna. Underneath the whole island chain, there is a bold legend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Five Deaths," it says. Slowly, an ocean barge starts to chug its way across the face of the map, leaving a wake that rolls the printed le of those three ominous words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The map dissolves slowly away as the barge SPALASEHS thro five foot ocean swells in the open sea. The barge is cram with equipment, the AAV, trailers, a jeep, and the member Malcolm's team.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BOAT,
dialogues.text: MALCOLM stands in the bow, riding the choppy seas. Next t him, DR. JUTTSON, fortyish, holds onto the railing, seasick. He SHOUTS over the DRONE of the boat's engines.

dialogues.speaker: JUTTISON
dialogues.text: (as the waves pound the boat) Couldn't -- we just -- airlift -- into the -- island?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Dr. Harding insisted we go by sea! Helicopters are too disruptive. These aren't piles of bones you'll be  studying this time, Dr. Juttson, they live, they breathe, and they react! Juttson looks at him skeptically -- -- and throws up.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BACK OF THE BOAT,
dialogues.text: NICK VAN OWEN, a good-looking American in his late twenties, is sitting amid a pile of video cameras and oth photographic equipment, playing with a Game Bow. SARAH HARDING, dressed in field gear, sits down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: So what's your story, Nick?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I was a cameraman for Nightline for six years, been freelance since '91. Do a lot of work for Greenpeace.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: That must be interesting. What drew you there?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Women. 'Bout eighty percent female in Greenpeace.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Very noble of you. (of the noisy Game Boy) You don't think you're bringing that thing onto the island, do you? Nick grins and shuts it off.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hey, I wouldn't want to spook the woolly mammoths.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You think this is all a joke?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh, please. How am I supposed to keep a straight face when -- (gestures to the black-clad Malcolm) -- Johnny Cash here tells me I'm going to Skull Island?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (not amused) Ian's a very good friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't need a friend, he needs a shrink.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I believe in him. But her face says even she has her doubts.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Come on, there's only one reason any of us are here. His check cleared. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Drop the cynical pose. You can't pull it off while playing Donkey Kong. The boat's CAPTAIN, a Costa Rican, points ahead and SHOUT them.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: There it is! They all turn and look out over the bow. Up ahead, shear, reddish-gray cliffs of volcanic rock rise dramatically ou the fog-heavy ocean. CAPTAIN (cont'd) Isla Sorna! The boat ROARS ahead, plowing into a heavy wreath of fog. mist swirls and encircles it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrow inlet cuts through the steep cliffs, leading to island interior. The barge bursts through the fog at the mouth of the fiord and heads deeper into the island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lush green plants drip everywhere in this verdant lagoon. Sulfurous yellow steam issues from the ground, bleaching nearby foliage white. In the distance one can hear the cr of JUNGLE BIRDS. The boat is now beached and the CREW flips the tarps off AAV, the jeep, and the trailers. The trucks back down a narrow ramp and onto the soft clay shore at the edge of t lagoon. There is a large three-toad animal imprint in the clay at the water's edge, and the AAV backs right over it swapping its track for the animal's. MALCOLM is at the edge of the water with the CAPTAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be back in three days, but keep the satellite phone on and your radio tuned to the frequency I specified in case we need you sooner.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I've lived around here all my life, these islands are completely -- In the distance, they hear the faint, strange ROAR of a v large animal. The Captain looks at Malcolm, eyes wide. CAPTAIN (cont'd) -- safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jeep tows the double trailer to the edge of a grassy just beyond the lagoon, overlooking the interior of the island. The noon sun is high overhead; below, the valley shimmers in midday heat. EDDIE connects a flexible cable to the jeep's power winch flicks it on. The cable turns slowly in the sunlight. Mov along the length of it, we see the cable leads to a pile aluminum, some kind of strut assembly painted a camouflag color. As the winch pulls the cable tight, the jumble of thin st begins to move, slowly rising into the air. The emerging structure climbs, spidery, struts unfolding, fifteen feet the air. The light house at the top (the cage that was tested back at Eddie's workshop) is now just beneath the lowest branches of the nearby trees, which almost conceal from view. NICK lights a cigarette and carelessly tosses the match o ground. Malcolm notices.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Listen. I know you all have probably concluded that I'm out of my mind. Is it our imagination, or did the trees behind Malcolm ju sway slightly? MALCOLM (cont'd) That's all right, for now. But just humor me and be careful. No, it's not our imagination, there they go again. Whole trees shivering and swaying from left to right and back  again. MALCOLM (cont'd) Even if you think I'm harmless and deluded, I promise -- Now the trees CREAKS and GROAN as they sway. Everyone has it, and now Malcolm turns around too. MALCOLM (cont'd) -- this place is for real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quiet inside the trailers that serve as their comman post/living quarters. The books are lined up neatly on th shelves. The computers sit, booted up and awaiting data input. All the way in the back, past the spare tires and life preservers and canned food and bottled water, up in one storage bin all the way on top, there's a RUSTLING SOUND. A plastic student ID card pops out in the cracks under th bin's door. A photograph in the lower right hand corner o the card is visible -- it's Kelly, Malcolm's twelve-year- daughter. The card wriggles against the lock and, with a soft CLICK door pops open. KELLY herself tumbles out, wrapped in sev blankets and carrying a mason jar half full of a yellowis liquid. We can guess. She leaps to her feet, blinks the light out of her eyes, bolts to the back of the trailer as fast as she possibly She races through a narrow door and SLAMS it shut. A sign on the door says "RESTROOM." Inside, a SIGH of rel is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along a stream bed, the jungle trees still shiver. NICK l a three quarter inch tape into his heavy video camera and chews anxiously on a piece of gum. SARAH and DR. JUTTSON beside him as the group nervously follows the GROANING fo trees to their right. At the rear, EDDIE and MALCOLM walk side by side. Eddie i carrying a heavy silver rifle, an aluminum canister hangi beneath the barrel. He shows it to Malcolm, his voice low urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindstradt air rifle. Fires a subsonic Fluger impact-delivery dart. He cracks open the cartridge bank, revealing a row of pla containers filled with straw-colored liquid. Each is tipp with a three inch needle and carries a bright yellow warn tag -- "EXTREME DANGER! LETHAL TOXICITY!" EDDIE (cont'd) I loaded the enhanced venom of Conus purpurascens, the South Sea cone shell. Most powerful neurotoxin in the world. Acts within a two-thousandth of a second. Faster than the nerve-conduction velocity. The animal's down before it feels the prick of the dart. From their right, the shaking trees seen closer now. By walking down the stream bed, the humans are tracking righ along with the animals as they move in the foliage.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: (to Eddie) Is there an antidote?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Like if you shoot yourself in the foot? Wouldn't matter. You'd be dead before you realized you'd accidentally pulled the trigger. Ahead of them, thick foliage blocks the path of the dried stream bed to the height of about fifteen feet. But aroun them, the CRASHING sounds get louder and closer, the sway trees shiver right beside them. Eddie raises the rifle in defense as the trees right at the edge of the stream bed and part. Above the foliage, they see the sudden movement --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- of a row of STEGOSAUR fins. The spade-shaped fins run along a ridge down the middle of the animal's back, about three feet tall each. The group freezes, amazed, and as t stegosaur continues on, they get a good look at it throug break in the foliage. It's a large dinosaur with a small head, a thick neck, an huge lumbering body. A double row of plates runs along the crest of its back, it has a dragging trail with long spikes in it. The gum drops out of Nick's mouth, FLOPS onto his shirt, sticks there.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh --

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: -- God!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It's beautiful! A second stegosaur, a baby about a quarter the size of th first animal, breaks through the foliage, following the a While the group is reaching to that, the earth vibrates a a third stego, by far the biggest of the three, walks out the foliage right behind them, crossing within ten feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently unconcerned about these little creatures in th environment, the stegos continue on across the stream bed Sarah raises a still camera and shoots pictures. Her shut is muted, so that a muffled CLICK is all that's audible. Juttson raises a pocket recorder to his lips and whispers it breathlessly.

dialogues.speaker: JUTTSON
dialogues.text: Stegosaurus, family Stegosauridae, infraorder Stegosauria, suborder Thyreophora. Length, adult male, estimate twenty-five to thirty feet. His breathy words turn into almost helpless laughter, of things, as he can't contain his astonishment. Eddie cover his mouth, trying to keep him quiet.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (to Juttsn) That was a pair bond! A family group, even, long after that infant was nestbound!

dialogues.speaker: JUTTSON
dialogues.text: I want to see the nesting ground! Nick turns to Malcolm, eyes like saucers, and makes a fut wordless, boy-was-I-wrong-on-this-one gesture. Malcolm smiles, leans over, and TAPS softly on Nick's video camer Nick raises it to his shoulder and flicks it on as the gr continues on into the bush after the animals.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BUSH,
dialogues.text: the baby wanders away from the group and ambles over near where Sarah crouches in the bushes. Sarah raises her came again and silently SNAPS a picture. She WHISPERS to Jutts  who is beside her.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Lone nest -- not colonial. I don't see an egg clutch... She gestures and Juttson peers through a pair of field glasses.

dialogues.speaker: JUTTSON
dialogues.text: (whispering back) The empty shells are crushed and trampled. The young stay in the birth environment, that's conclusive!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Not without a shot of the nest. She sees an opportunity. As the baby heads back to its parents, Sarah scoots right along with it, moving behind using its body as a shield to block her from the view of other two. Nick and Eddie's faces whiten in alarm. Nick reaches out stop her, but he barely gets hold of the sole of her boot before she pulls away from him and duckwalks out into the clearing.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CLEARING,
dialogues.text: Sarah slinks along behind the baby stego as it walks back toward the nest, chewing the branches it carries in its s She raises up sightly, squeezing off pictures of the herd ever better as she gets closer.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE HILL,
dialogues.text: the others can only watch her, aghast.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: She's gutty.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: She's nuts.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CLEARING,
dialogues.text: Sarah keeps moving closer. The baby passes a small groupi of rocks and Sarah ducks behind them. She's now in a perf position to photograph the nest, and she squeezes off pic after picture from this ideal vantage point. She shoots the last picture on the roll -- -- and the camera's autowinder WHIRS to life. Sarah looks down in horror as the camera's motor WHINES loudly in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Th noise startles the animals. The male turns toward her the plates on its back bristling. Sarah gets to her feet starts to move away, slowly. The male turns away from her and swings its tail, spikes extended. It WHIZZES through the air, right at her, but S leaps back at the last second -- -- and the tail's spikes THUD into the dirt where she was Sarah CRUNCHES to the ground and the three stegosaurs dar away, disappearing into the bush, moving surprisingly qui for animals their size. The others run to Sarah, help her to her feet, and pull h back, against a massive tree trunk. But the tree trunk li right up off the ground. It's no tree, it's a DINOSAUR'S LEG, a massive one, six f across, God knows how many feet high. The Group gasps and looks up as a MAKENCHIASAURUS, an enormous saurupod over hundred feet from nose to tail, lumbers away from them. The Group stares in wonder as the mamenchiasaur stops and HONKS furtively, its long neck stretched out above them. Now a second mamenchiasaur neck cranes out of the surrounding forest trees and wraps around the first. The first mamenchiasaur THUNDERS around in a semi-circle, get into position behind the second. Nick swings his video camera straight up and the group suddenly finds itself in the middle of a mamenchiasaur ma The mighty tails swing and SNAP around them as the two an come together, and trees start snapping and falling, CRAS to the jungle floor. The group panics and bolts for cover toward the only plac where the trees are not falling -- which is directly unde the animals! Amid HONKS and BLEATS, the swinging tails continue to def the jungle around them. The noise and chaos is deafening, drowning out the LAUGHT and SCREAMS of the fascinated and terrified group. There is a momentary lull and the group dashes out from underneath the animals, disappearing into the thick fores

dialogues.speaker: A SHORT DISTANCE AWAY,
dialogues.text: the Group collapses to the ground, breathless, chests hea with wild, frightened laughter. Sarah goes to Malcolm and throws her arms around him, exhilarated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tan, you're not insane! I'm so glad! —

dialogues.speaker: JUTTSON
dialogues.text: (out of breath) Dr. Malcolm -- the world -- owes you an apology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the Gathereres are taking their expedition a lo seriously. They march quickly back to base camp, their en and excitement palpable. NICK strikes a match and raises to a cigarette with a shaking hand, but SARAH leans in an blows it out.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No more smoking. We leave no scent of any kind. No hair tonics, no cologne, seal all our food in plastic bags. We will observe and document, but we will not interact.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: That's a scientific impossibility, you know. Heisenberg uncertainty principle. Whatever you study, you also change. Nick ejects the used videotape from his camera and pulls sharpie, to label it.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What should I call this? "Jurassic Pork?" Eddie, next to him, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (still to Malcolm) And let's forget about the high hide. We can't do this kind of work up in a tower, we need to be out in the field, as close to the animals as possible.

dialogues.speaker: JUTTSON
dialogues.text: I'm not surprised stegosaur lived in a family group, but there's never been anything in the fossil record to prove the carnivores did.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Why wouldn't they? Look at hyenas, jackals, nearly all species of predator birds --

dialogues.speaker: JUTTSON
dialogues.text: That doesn't say a thing about T-rex, they could have been rogues. Robert Burke certainly thinks they were.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: We've got to see one to find out. Is there any —

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh, my God.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: -- way we could safely --

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh, no! He takes off, running as fast as he can, down the trail, toward base camp. They look ahead, in the direction Nick running. A plume of black smoke is rising up over the tre

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NICK bursts out of the trees and races toward the thick p of smoke. In the middle of the base camp, someone has nea built a campfire surrounded by stones. Flames burn in the middle. Nick races over to it and stomps it out as the OTHERS eme from the trees behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: A campfire?! Nick grabs a jug of water, but Sarah steps in.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No! Water mixes the smoke billow, use dirt! They start to kick and rake dirt onto the fire with their hands and feet. Eddie and Dr. Juttson jump in and help ou

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Who the hell started a campfire?! VOICE (0.s.) It was just to make lunch. Malcolm turns toward the source of the voice. KELLY stand the doorway of the trailer, sheepish. KELLY (cont'd) I wanted it ready when you got back. The whole group stares, stunned, none more so than Malcol himself.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Oh ... man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, and base camp is a blur of activity. SARAH, JUTTSO NICK, and EDDIE are hard at work, burying the remains of fire, sealing their food in plastic bags, loading camera equipment, packing up specimen containers and other information-gathering equipment. MALCOLM, meanwhile, is lecturing Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You know you were putting yourself in a potentially dangerous situation, but you didn't bother to find out how dangerous before you leapt in. You don't have the faintest idea what's going on on this island!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (loading a backpack) What do you want to do, Ian, lock her up for curiosity? Where do you think she gets it?

dialogues.speaker: JUTTSON
dialogues.text: (to Nick) Do you have chromium tapes? The others fog in high-

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: -humidity, I know. (waving a tape) Highest lead density on the market.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (to Malcolm) We've got a lot of heavy marching ahead of us. I'm not carrying  anybody.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I can keep up.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You're going home. I'm sending a radio call for the boats. We'll all go down to the lagoon and wait for them.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Lighten up, Ian, you sound like a high school vice-principal.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: I'm her father.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Sure, now. Nick leans over and whispers to Eddie, gesturing to Malco and Kelly.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Do you see any family resemblance here?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: You can't stay, Kelly, that's it. It's too dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: If it's so dangerous, why'd you bring any of us?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You're wrong, Dad. I do know what's going on on this island.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: How could you possibly?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Because you said so. Maybe nobody else believed you, but I always did. ~ He looks at her, touched. Nick mutters to Eddie again.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: The kid scores with cheap sentiment.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Ian, if we recall the boat now, we've made two invasive landings in one day. That'll have to go in any paper  I write, and it will leave room for people to say our findings were contaminated. You know the academic world as well as I do, once they smell blood in the water, you're dead. Our presence has got to be one hundred percent antiseptic. That means if we bend a blade of grass, we bend it right back the way it- A low sound has been rising while she speaks, and now it BOOMING over the jungle around them, a THUNDEROUS racket shakes the very ground beneath them. Suddenly, three C-13 military cargo planes THUNDER overhead and ROAR toward th island interior, flying very low. The planes are enormous fat-assed creatures, their rear cargo doors hanging open.

dialogues.speaker: AT A RIDGE,
dialogues.text: the members of the gatherer expedition hit the dirt and p over a ledge, watching as the airplanes bank and circle o specific spot. Eddie raises a pair of field glasses.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN BELOW,
dialogues.text: huge metal equipment containers are shoved out the back o cargo bays. They SNAP off trees like matchsticks, CRUSH f anything foolish enough to exist where they want to land. Now MEN pour out the rear of the planes, their low-altitu parachutes billowing open behind them.

dialogues.speaker: UP ON THE RIDGE,
dialogues.text: Nick looks at Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You were saying something about antiseptic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metal container doors CLANG to the ground, jeep engines R to life in a cloud of thick black diesel smoke, blue lase barriers SIZZLE and BURN through foliage as this group of HUNTERS establishes a perimeter around their new camp. PETER LUDLOW, dressed in brand new Banana Republic safari wear, steps into the center of the camp and surveys the surroundings. He turns to DR. ROBERT BURKE, a ragged, pony-tailed man in wire-rimmed glasses.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Welcome to your dream come true, Dr. Burke. Burke has a detailed set of satellite recon photographs t he spreads out on the hood of a jeep.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: I believe the large herbivores forage in open plains, like bison, which would explain the great variety of heat dots we're reading in the flatlands around this waterhole. Right -- here.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Then that's where we're going. Burke flips open a manifest that he will carry with him a times. Inside, there are dozens of sketches of various ki underneath. As each vehicle ROARS out of the equipment container, Burke slips a waterproof eight by ten card wit icon of the various dinosaurs on the island into a slot i dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (calling them off) Hadrosaurus! Carinthosaurus! Maiasaurus! As the procession goes on, Ludlow turns to DIETER STARK, man we saw welding earlier.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: This is as good a place as any for base camp. First priority is the laser barriers, I want them all up and running in thirty minutes. Half an hour, understand? Dieter nods and turns to some of the HUNTERS, who number twenty in all, that are working nearby. But someone steps front of Dieter, cutting him off. It's ROLAND TEMBO, the hunter from the bar in Mombassa.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Cancel that, Dieter.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: What? Why? Roland points to a stream running nearby.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Carnivores hunt near stream beds. Do you want to set up base camp or an all-you-can-eat people bar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks) You heard his, Dieter. Find a new spot. And remember, we're after herbivores only -- no unnecessary risks. Dieter SIGHS and goes to work. Roland puts an arm around Ludlow and pulls him aside.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Peter, if you want me to run your little camping trip, there are two conditions. First -- I'm in charge, and when I'm not around, Dieter is. Your job is to sign the checks, tellus we're doing a good job, and open your case of scotch when we have a good day. Second condition -- my fee. You can keep it. All I want in exchange for my services is the right to hunt one of the tyrannosaurs. A male. Buck only. Why and how are my business. If you don't like either of those conditions, you're on your own. Go ahead and set up your camp right here, or in a swamp, or in the middle of a rex nest, for all I care. But I've been on too many safaris with rich dentists to listen to any more suicidal ideas. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (what else can he say?) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Good lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jungle foliage shivers, quakes, and finally falls as Hunters' convoy ROARS into the hart of the jungle. DIETER STARK stands in the front of the lead vehicle, the "speedbird," waving the convoy forward, his Driver (CARTE the wheel beside him. LUDLOW is in the back seat of the speedbird next to DR. B ROLAND and AJAY, his tracker, are in the second jeep. The look up as the brakelights on the speedbird flash and the stops, forcing the rest of the convoy to halt as well. In the front, the speedbird flashes its lights at somethi front of it. Dieter climbs out, plainly irritated. He wal  around the front of the car and sees -- -- four PACHYCEPHALOSAURS eating grass in the middle of t jungle trail. They're about five feet tall, thick, heavy- animals whose distinctive feature is an enormous skull ca a tall, impressive crown that rises on the tops of their heads. Dieter doesn't seem impressed. He looks back at Ludlow, who look at Dr. Burke. Burke stands up in his seat, a look of wonder on his face

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: Pachycephalosaurus!

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Carnivore?

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (enchanted) Huh? No! No, herbivore, late Cretaceous. Very unusual plant eater, see that distinctive domed skull? That's nine inches of solid bone.

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: (who cares?) Just get them out of the way, Dieter.

dialogues.speaker: COME ON, MOVE IT
dialogues.text: The pachys look up at him sluggishly, still eating, like chewing their cuds. As unimpressive with him as he is wit them, they go back to their grass. DIETER (cont'd) Oh, for God's -- He slings his rifle off his shoulder and aims it at the closest animal. Behind him, Roland has climbed out of the second jeep.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Dieter. This is a round-up, not a war. Use your powers of persuasion. Dieter gestures to the speedbird to pull ahead, which it slowly, toward the animals. The pachys look up, alert, bu not move. Dieter walks toward them.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Come on, come on, don't have all day!

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (going on to no one in  particular) See, the pachy's neck attaches at the bottom of its skull instead of the back of its head, as with reptiles. The speedbird draws closer. The first pachy stares at it intently. The lead vehicle gets closer, closer -- -- and BANGS into the pachy, knocking it back a few feet, of the way. BURKE (cont'd) So when it lowers its head, its neck lines up directly with its backbone --

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND DIETER,
dialogues.text: Ajay is staring at something on the ground at his feet. H takes a few steps further into the foliage, then turns ba toward Roland.

dialogues.speaker: AJAY
dialogues.text: Roland.

dialogues.speaker: UP AT THE FRONT,
dialogues.text: the pachys turn and hop away. Dieter turns and heads back the speedbird. As he reaches for the door, a VOICE calls "look out!" from behind him. Dieter spins around, just in time to see -- -- the first pachy in full charge. It SLAMS headfirst int the speedbird, SMASHING the headlights and denting the gr

dialogues.speaker: BURKE
dialogues.text: (concluding his lecture) Which is perfect for absorbing impact. Dieter turns and runs around to the front of the car. The pachy has backed up for another run and is now CHARGING R AT HIM. Dieter retreats, quickly, and rips open the passenger doo protect himself. SLAM! The pachy clobbers the door, sending Dieter flying against the car, knocking the wind out of him. In the other jeeps, the rest of the HUNTERS stand up or l out the window for a better look, laughing. Pow!! The pachy head-butts the tire next to Dieter. It bounces off, tumbles to the ground, and rolls to its feet Dieter gets to his knees and crawls toward the back of th speedbird. But the pachy is quicker and lunges at Dieter again. He' forced to hit the dirt and crawls quickly underneath the speedbird, just as the animal SLAMS into the rear of the vehicle. Now the other three animals join the jun. Ludlow and the Driver have to cover their heads as the animals lunge at car again and again, SMASHING the steel-meshed windows an MANGLING the quarter panels. The rest of the group watche vastly amused.

dialogues.speaker: A FEW STEPS INTO THE JUNGLE,
dialogues.text: Ajay and Roland are staring at something on the ground -- animal footprint, three-toed, enormous.

dialogues.speaker: AJAY
dialogues.text: It matches the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: It certainly does. Roland gets up and goes back to his vehicle, ignoring the pachy demolition derby that continues up at the speedbird Roland opens a case in the back of the jeep, revealing -- -- his gun. It's an antique elephant gun, a double barrel .600 Nitro Express. Nearly a hundred years old, it's stil immaculate condition, its rosewood stock buttery smooth, bisons delicately engraved along its silver breach. The barrels are twenty-four inches long, topped with an i bead foresight at the business end. Roland scoops up the breaks the breach, and pulls two rounds of ammunition fro shirt pocket. Four inches long and three-quarters of an inch in diamete these are the largest full metal jacket cartridges ever m He slips one into each barrel and heads back into the bus Roland pauses before he goes, as if noticing the animals trashing the speedbird for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: HEY
dialogues.text: The pachys all freeze, staring at him. Roland waves one h HISSES sharply between his teeth -- -- and the pachys scatter, back into the jungle. Takes ca of that problem. Roland turns and heads back into the jun calling out over his shoulder to Ludlow. ROLAND (cont'd) Don't worry about us. We'll catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think you're going?!

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: To collect my fee. And with that he disappears into the foliage. The Driver of the Speedbird drops it into gear and the battered car GROANS forward. As it moves ahead, it reveal DIETER, lying underneath it, ego bruised worse than body.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE JUNGLE,
dialogues.text: Ajay takes a step into the bush, but at a ninety degree angle away from the direction in which the animals tracks lead.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: Ajay. Ajay turns. Roland points in the direction in which the footprints lead. ROLAND (cont'd) I'm no tracker, but even I can read this spoor.

dialogues.speaker: AJAY
dialogues.text: Do you wish to go where the animal has been, or where the animal is? Roland smiles. Ajay sets off in his direction and Roland follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen from a ridge above them, the hunters’ convoy continu plow through the jungle. But how the hunters themselves a being tracked, followed by the GATHERERS. They scurry alo as fast as they can, trying to keep pace with the moving vehicle below.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell us about these guys, Ian?!

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Because I didn't know! I don't have the faintest idea what they're doing here.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (angry)  Ruining everything, that's what they're doing. You could choke on the diesel smoke already!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Ian, nothing we observe will be valid if we're trailing along in the wake of an army. Kelly has a pair of binoculars and is studying the vehicl they move below.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: "InGen." What's InGen?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: Where does it say that?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: On the side of that one truck. Malcolm takes the binoculars and stares down there himsel

dialogues.speaker: JUTTSON
dialogues.text: InGen is a genetics corporation isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to Malcolm) Is that who we're really working

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: for?! Gene splicers?!

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: No! We're an independently funded expedition.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Funded by whom?

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: John Hammond.

dialogues.speaker: JUTTSON
dialogues.text: But he's the head of InGen!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding. (to Malcolm) You dragged me out of Greenpeace to be a corporate stooge? You couldn't get anybody else?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, what have you done, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: We'd better keep moving, or we'll  lose them. The group moves on ahead, but Malcolm lingers, angry, sta through the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: MALCOLM
dialogues.text: What are you doing to me, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AJAY and ROLAND make their way through the foliage and co into a small clearing, where a cluster of caves is carved the rock. Ajay freezes, gesturing ahead, to the cave on t far left. Roland pulls up a handful of grass and releases it on the breeze. It floats back between his legs. That's good. He proceeds toward the cave, carefully, Ajay behind him. can see nothing beyond the yawning mouth of the cave, onl black interior. Roland pauses, looking down. On the ground to his right h sees the partially eastern leg of a creature. It's old, crawling with white maggots and flies. Roland continues on. Closer to the cave, he now passes th skull of a large animal, some of the flesh and green skin still adhering to the bone. It, too, is covered with flie Still he continues on. A short rise leads into the cave, they edge up it. From inside the cave, they can hear an o SQUEAKING sound, very high-pitched. Crawling now, Roland and Ajay scale a four-foot circular rampart of dried mud, and peer into -- -- the tyrannosaur nest. It's flattered inside, about ten feet in diameter, completely encircled by earthen walls. A BABY TYRANNOSAUR, about four and a half feet long, is i center of the nest. It has a large head, very large eyes, its body is covered with a fluffy red down, which gives i scraggly appearance. It SQUEAKS repeatedly, tearing awkwardly at the remains o chunk of animal flesh, biting decisively with tiny, sharp teeth. The cave itself is a foul boneyard. ANIMAL CARCASSES litt the edges, flies BUZZ in the captive air. Roland raises a bandana to his nose to cover the stench. He turns to Ajay WHISPERS.

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: It's the rex nest. Ajay nods. The baby tyrannosaur hears the whisper and loo up, cocking its head in curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: AJAY
dialogues.text: Make a blind here? Wait for the buck to return?

dialogues.speaker: ROLAND
dialogues.text: (shakes his head no) If the nest is upwind, so are we. When he comes back, he'll know we're here before we have a chance. The truck -- In the nest below, the baby SQUEAKS angrily at the intrud ROLAND (cont'd) -- is to get him to come where we want him. The baby SQUEAKS again, indignant. Roland turns and looks down at it. Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the sun glows bright orange on the horizon, NICK raise pair of binoculars to his eyes and peers down at the vist below the ridge. In the lenses of the binoculars, we can clearly see a mix herd of midsized herbivores -- HARDOSAURS, PACHYCEPHALOSA and CALLIMIMUSES -- racing across the plain below. MALCOLM, also staring through binoculars, lies on the rid beside him. SARAH is several feet behind them, her back pressed against a tree, unwilling to go to the lip of the ridge.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH NICK'S BINOCULARS
dialogues.text: We see a shaky point of view of the herd running. The binoculars whip to the right -- -- revealing a jeep chasing the herd Not just one jeep, i fact, but a whole FLEET OF HUNTER PURSUIT VEHICLES! There are two herding jeeps, one motorcycle, as speedier mini-jeep, and, further behind, a container truck and a wrangler's pickup truck. Although there's a great deal of commotion below, up here almost eerily silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick lowers the binoculars, angry. When he raises them ag the sun FLARES off the lens --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and when the brilliant flare clears, we're right down the middle of the roundup. Engines ROAR, wheels spin and in the dirt, men SHOUT and radios SQUAWK as the hunter vehicles pursue the fleeting herd they're flushed. The HUNTER SHOUT and SHRIEK with glee, incredulous and thrilled by the spectacular animals they're pursuing.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUTIFUL
dialogues.text: One of the pursuit vehicles (a "snagger"), pulls ahead of others. DIETER STARK stands in the passenger seat, holdin long pole with a noose dangling from the end of it. He swings the pole out over the side of the jeep and SHOU the driver.

dialogues.speaker: FASTER
dialogues.text: The Driver hits the gas and the snagger leaps forward, ga on the herd. Aware of the danger behind them, the herd ve to the right, toward the cover of thick jungle -- -- but the motorcycle ROARS in from the right side, cutti them off, herding them back out into the open.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE CONTAINER TRUCK,
dialogues.text: PETER LUDLOW stands in a "conning tower," a command post the heaviest pursuit vehicle. He BARKS into a walkie-talk

dialogues.speaker: LUDLOW
dialogues.text: Alive, Dieter, and uninjured!

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON THE SNAGGER,
dialogues.text: the Driver can barely keep up with the twists and feints thrown by the herd ahead of him. Dieter CURSES and throws lasso pole into the back of the jeep. Ludlow's voice continues over the radio in Dieter's jeep. LUDLOW (0.s.) Those are very expensive animals! Can you hear me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Driver) Turn that off! The Driver SNAPS off the radio as Dieter grabs a long-bar rifle from the back of the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: THE MOTORCYCLE
dialogues.text: guns it again, forcing the herd back into the middle of t plain. From the trees to the left, two heads on enormous necks rise up in alarm. Two APATOSAURS are startled from bush and lumber out across the middle of the plain. The herd doesn't even break stride, but keeps running, scampering after the giants and stampeding right between massive legs. One smaller pachycephalosaur bolts loose, but the motorcy cuts it off and herds it back into the middle, which now the motorcycle right through the rising and falling legs the apotosaurs. The bike chases the pachy out the other side, and as the apatosaurs disappear into the distance, the cycle isolate juvenile. Another truck, a "scissor rig," spots the isolated animal High in the back of the truck, a HUNTER mans a tranquiliz cannon, drawing a bead on the pachy as the cycle runs it He FIRES and the tranquilizer dart hits the animal in the neck. Its pace slows and another HUNTER from the truck to a lasso around its neck. They crank a winch, reeling in the animal. As the truck gain on it, two six-foot padded arms with wh look like heavy airbags on the insides open up on the fro the truck. As the animal is pulled in, the scissors close with a hydraulic WHIR, trapping the animal between its airbags. Now a pick-up rig ROARS up and drops its back gate. The scissor rig rolls forward, depositing the squirming pachy this dino-contaiment vehicle. Two HUNTERS throw levers on the side of the scissor bars the scissor rig backs away, leaving the animal, still pin between the bars, imprisoned in the back of the pick-up r The Hunters quickly fit new scissor bars onto the scissor and it takes off, back into the hunt.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON THE SNAGGER,
dialogues.text: Dieter, rifle in hand, drops down into the passenger sea whips a harness over himself and CLICKS it into place. He jabs his thumb into a flashing red button in the dashboar Immediately, a motor underneath the seat HUMS to life and seat itself telescopes, extending a good four feet out to Dieter raises the gun, picks a CARINTHOSAUR, a red-creste herbivore, from the rear of the fleeting herd, and takes

dialogues.speaker: BANG
dialogues.text: The carinthosaur staggers as a tranquilizer dart sticks i its left hindquarter.

dialogues.speaker: UP ON THE RIDGE,
dialogues.text: there is utter quiet. Nick and the others stare wordlessl the spectacle below.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN ON THE PLAIN,
dialogues.text: the snagger SHUDDERS to a halt in the dirt, kicking up a cloud of dust and dirt. The motorcycle spins to a stop beside it, its DRIVER push his mask up to reveal his sweat and dirt-streaked face. The wrangler truck backs up and drops its rear door, whic CLANGS heavily to the ground. FOUR WRANGLERS carrying wire noose poles and chains race the ramp and out of the truck. Dieter jumps off the snagger. He puts down his tranquiliz gun, picks up a long steel rod, and walks forward slowly. Ahead of him, the carinthosaur is still on its feet. The sedated animal staggers, fighting to retain its balan while it is surrounded by the wary Wranglers.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Easy -- easy -- not too close! Full extension! The Wranglers adjust their poles, extending them another feet, which allows them to stay further from the reeling, foot tall animal. DIETER (cont'd) Now! Almost as one, the Wranglers flip their noose over the stunned animal's neck. It thrashes, but the Wranglers hol their poles tightly, surrounding and immobilizing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick turns away. He can't watch.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN ON THE PLAIN,
dialogues.text: a bolero-type device, a rope with a round weight at eithe end, whips around the carinthosaur's legs. The animal THU to the dirt with a SNORT of a defeat. Ludlow steps up next to Dieter and both of them stare dow the helpless animal. Ludlow's breathing heavily, eyes glowing. The animal is still thrashing, pumping its legs crazily. Dieter turns a knob on the side of the steel rod he's hol and thrusts it into the defenseless animal's neck. A blue arc of electricity CRACKS and dances over the carinthosaur's body. The animal convulses in pain, a horrible, high-pitched SQUEALING rips the air. DR. BURKE, their paleontologist, hurries forward with a syringe. He draws a certain amount of tranquilizer from a bottle a injects it into the animal's thigh. CARTER, Dieter's Driver, steps up with a can of spray pai and quickly tags the animal with an ID number in day-glo orange.
